code_value: The Great Fire of London started in the early hours of September 2, 1666. Within four days, it destroyed more than four-fifths of the old city, where most of the houses were wooden and close together. It was estimated that around 70,000 people became homeless, but only a few lost their lives. The fire started on Sunday morning in the house of a famous baker in Pudding Lane. On Monday, nearly a kilometer of the city was burning along the River Thames. Thursday was the worst day, when the fire destroyed many well-known buildings.
